justification: Analyzed package instability I = Ce/(Ce+Ca) = 24/(24+15) ≈ 0.615. It depends on multiple packages whose instability is higher than 0.615, i.e. they are less stable: net.bytebuddy.dynamic.scaffold.subclass (Ce=20, Ca=9, I≈0.690), net.bytebuddy.utility.visitor (Ce=6, Ca=3, I≈0.667), net.bytebuddy.asm (Ce=23, Ca=11, I≈0.676), net.bytebuddy.implementation.auxiliary (Ce=17, Ca=9, I≈0.654), net.bytebuddy.dynamic.scaffold.inline (Ce=20, Ca=7, I≈0.741). Because the package depends on these less stable packages (higher I), the Stable Dependencies Principle is violated and the Unstable Dependency smell is detected.

Analyzed package metrics: Ce=9, Ca=7 -> instability I = 9/(9+7) = 0.5625. It has an outgoing dependency to net.bytebuddy.implementation.auxiliary which has Ce=17, Ca=9 -> instability I = 17/(17+9) = 0.6538. Because net.bytebuddy.implementation.auxiliary is less stable (higher instability) than the analyzed package, this violates the Stable Dependencies Principle (a package should depend only on packages that are more stable). All other outgoing dependencies are more stable (examples: net.bytebuddy.utility I≈0.390, net.bytebuddy.build I≈0.345, net.bytebuddy.description.method I≈0.306, net.bytebuddy.implementation.bytecode I≈0.154, net.bytebuddy I≈0.490, net.bytebuddy.description.field I≈0.240, net.bytebuddy.description.type I≈0.333, net.bytebuddy.implementation I≈0.479), so the presence of the dependency on net.bytebuddy.implementation.auxiliary (I=0.6538 > 0.5625) is the reason for detecting an Unstable Dependency smell.

net.bytebuddy.matcher has Ce=9, Ca=23 => instability I=9/(9+23)=0.281. It has outgoing dependencies whose instability is higher than 0.281, i.e. dependencies on less stable packages: net.bytebuddy (Ce=25,Ca=26,I=0.490), net.bytebuddy.dynamic.loading (Ce=15,Ca=19,I=0.441), net.bytebuddy.utility (Ce=16,Ca=25,I=0.390), net.bytebuddy.description.annotation (Ce=12,Ca=19,I=0.387), net.bytebuddy.build (Ce=19,Ca=36,I=0.345), net.bytebuddy.description.type (Ce=16,Ca=32,I=0.333), net.bytebuddy.description.method (Ce=11,Ca=25,I=0.306). Only net.bytebuddy.description.field (I=0.240) and net.bytebuddy.description (I=0.250) are more stable. Because net.bytebuddy.matcher (relatively stable, Ca>Ce) depends on multiple less stable packages, it violates the Stable Dependencies Principle -> Unstable Dependency smell detected.

The package has Ce=9 and Ca=0 -> instability I = 9/(9+0) = 1.0 (maximally unstable). The Stable Dependencies Principle requires that a package only depends on packages with lower instability. All outgoing dependencies are more stable (have lower I) than the analyzed package: net.bytebuddy.pool I≈0.577 (Ce=15,Ca=11), net.bytebuddy.dynamic I≈0.522 (Ce=24,Ca=22), net.bytebuddy.asm I≈0.676 (Ce=23,Ca=11), net.bytebuddy.dynamic.scaffold.inline I≈0.741 (Ce=20,Ca=7), net.bytebuddy.build I≈0.345 (Ce=19,Ca=36), net.bytebuddy I≈0.490 (Ce=25,Ca=26), net.bytebuddy.description.type I≈0.333 (Ce=16,Ca=32), org.gradle.api.tasks I=0.0 (Ce=0,Ca=2), org.gradle.api.provider I=0.0 (Ce=0,Ca=3). There are no incoming dependencies (Ca=0) pointing to this package. Because every outgoing dependency is to a more stable package, the Unstable Dependency smell is not detected.

org.gradle.api.provider has no outgoing dependencies (Ce = 0) and therefore does not depend on any less-stable packages. Its afferent coupling is Ca = 3, giving stability I = Ca/(Ca+Ce) = 3/(3+0) = 1.0 (very stable). The incoming dependents are net.bytebuddy.build.gradle.android (Ca=0, Ce=9, I=0.0), org.gradle.work (Ca=1, Ce=1, I=0.5) and org.gradle.api.file (Ca=1, Ce=1, I=0.5); these packages depend on org.gradle.api.provider (incoming), not the other way around. Because there are no outgoing dependencies to less stable packages, the Unstable Dependency smell is not present.

The package has Ce=0 and Ca=2 (instability I = Ce/(Ca+Ce) = 0.0), and no outgoing dependencies. It does not depend on any other packages (outgoing_dependencies empty), so it cannot depend on less-stable packages. Incoming dependencies come from net.bytebuddy.build.gradle.android (Ce=9, Ca=0) and net.bytebuddy.build.gradle (Ce=8, Ca=0) which are unstable but depend on org.gradle.api.tasks. Dependency direction is toward the more stable package, so the Unstable Dependency smell is not present.

net.bytebuddy.implementation.bytecode has Ce=4 and Ca=22 -> instability I = 4/(22+4) = 0.154 (relatively stable). Its outgoing dependencies are less stable (higher I): net.bytebuddy.description.type (Ce=16, Ca=32, I=16/48=0.333), net.bytebuddy.build (Ce=19, Ca=36, I=19/55=0.345), net.bytebuddy.description.method (Ce=11, Ca=25, I=11/36=0.306), net.bytebuddy.implementation (Ce=23, Ca=25, I=23/48=0.479). Because this package (low I) depends on packages with higher instability (higher I), it violates the Stable Dependencies Principle and exhibits the Unstable Dependency smell.

Analyzed package net.bytebuddy.utility.visitor has Ce=6, Ca=3 -> instability I = 6/(6+3) = 0.667. Its outgoing dependencies are to packages that are more stable (lower I): net.bytebuddy.utility (Ce=16, Ca=25, I=0.390), net.bytebuddy.dynamic (Ce=24, Ca=22, I=0.522), net.bytebuddy.build (Ce=19, Ca=36, I=0.346), net.bytebuddy.description.method (Ce=11, Ca=25, I=0.306), net.bytebuddy.implementation.bytecode (Ce=4, Ca=22, I=0.154), net.bytebuddy.implementation (Ce=23, Ca=25, I=0.479). Because all outgoing dependencies have lower instability than net.bytebuddy.utility.visitor, the Stable Dependency Principle is respected and there is no unstable-dependency smell. (Incoming packages: net.bytebuddy.dynamic I=0.522, net.bytebuddy.dynamic.scaffold I=0.615, net.bytebuddy.asm I=0.677 — although net.bytebuddy.asm is marginally less stable than this package, it is an incoming dependency (it depends on net.bytebuddy.utility.visitor), so it does not cause an unstable dependency for net.bytebuddy.utility.visitor.)

Package com.service.definition has no outgoing dependencies (Ce = 0) and no incoming dependencies (Ca = 0). With no outgoing dependencies there is nothing it depends on, so it cannot depend on less-stable packages; therefore the Stable Dependencies Principle is not violated.

net.bytebuddy.utility has Ce=16, Ca=25 -> stability I = 25/(25+16) = 0.61. It has outgoing dependencies to several packages whose stability I is lower than 0.61, violating the Stable Dependencies Principle: net.bytebuddy.utility.dispatcher (Ce=6, Ca=8, I=0.57), net.bytebuddy.pool (Ce=15, Ca=11, I=0.42), net.bytebuddy.dynamic (Ce=24, Ca=22, I=0.48), net.bytebuddy.utility.privilege (Ce=1, Ca=1, I=0.50), net.bytebuddy.description.module (Ce=8, Ca=9, I=0.53), net.bytebuddy.dynamic.loading (Ce=15, Ca=19, I=0.56) and net.bytebuddy (Ce=25, Ca=26, I=0.51). Because net.bytebuddy.utility depends on these less-stable packages, an Unstable Dependency smell is detected (even though some dependencies are more stable, multiple unstable outgoing dependencies cause the smell).

Ce=0 and Ca=0 with no outgoing_dependencies and no incoming_dependencies. The package does not depend on any other packages (outgoing empty), so it cannot depend on less stable components and the Stable Dependencies Principle is not violated.

Analyzed package stability I = Ca/(Ca+Ce) = 19/(19+15) = 0.559. It has 15 outgoing dependencies; 6 of them are less stable (I < 0.559): net.bytebuddy.dynamic (Ca=22, Ce=24, I=0.478), net.bytebuddy.dynamic.scaffold (Ca=15, Ce=24, I=0.385), net.bytebuddy.description.module (Ca=9, Ce=8, I=0.529), net.bytebuddy (Ca=26, Ce=25, I=0.510), net.bytebuddy.dynamic.scaffold.subclass (Ca=9, Ce=20, I=0.310), net.bytebuddy.implementation (Ca=25, Ce=23, I=0.521). Several of these (for example net.bytebuddy.dynamic and net.bytebuddy.dynamic.scaffold) also list net.bytebuddy.dynamic.loading among their dependencies (incoming), indicating mutual/cyclic dependencies that exacerbate the violation of the Stable Dependencies Principle. Because the package depends on multiple less-stable components and has cyclic ties with them, the Unstable Dependency smell is detected.

It has 16 outgoing dependencies; 11 of them have higher instability (i.e. are less stable) than 0.333, indicating an unstable dependency direction. Outgoing dependencies and their instabilities: net.bytebuddy.utility (Ce=16, Ca=25, I=0.390 - more stable), net.bytebuddy.asm (Ce=23, Ca=11, I=0.677 - less stable), net.bytebuddy.dynamic.scaffold (Ce=24, Ca=15, I=0.615 - less stable), net.bytebuddy.build (Ce=19, Ca=36, I=0.345 - more stable), net.bytebuddy.description.method (Ce=11, Ca=25, I=0.306 - more stable), net.bytebuddy (Ce=25, Ca=26, I=0.490 - less stable). Outgoing dependencies with higher instability: net.bytebuddy.dynamic (Ce=24, Ca=22, I=0.522), net.bytebuddy.dynamic.scaffold (Ce=24, Ca=15, I=0.615), net.bytebuddy.dynamic.scaffold.subclass (Ce=20, Ca=9, I=0.690), net.bytebuddy.implementation.bind (Ce=8, Ca=3, I=0.727), net.bytebuddy.implementation.bytecode.member (Ce=12, Ca=11, I=0.522), net.bytebuddy.implementation.bind.annotation (Ce=20, Ca=3, I=0.870), net.bytebuddy.implementation.bytecode.constant (Ce=9, Ca=7, I=0.563), net.bytebuddy.implementation.auxiliary (Ce=17, Ca=9, I=0.654), net.bytebuddy (Ce=25, Ca=26, I=0.490), net.bytebuddy.implementation.attribute (Ce=9, Ca=8, I=0.529). net.bytebuddy.description.modifier has Ce=1 and Ca=16 (instability I = 1/(1+16) ≈ 0.059). It has an outgoing dependency only to net.bytebuddy.build, which has Ce=19 and Ca=36 (instability I = 19/(19+36) ≈ 0.345). Because the analyzed package is much more stable (lower I) than the package it depends on (higher I), the dependency direction is from a more stable package to a less stable one — violating the Stable Dependencies Principle. Incoming coupling (Ca=16) shows many packages depend on net.bytebuddy.description.modifier, reinforcing that it is a stable package; its dependence on the less stable net.bytebuddy.build is therefore an unstable dependency smell.

net.bytebuddy.build.gradle has Ce=8 and Ca=0 giving stability I = 0.0 (highly unstable). net.bytebuddy.android has Ce=7 and Ca=0 (stability I=0.00). All outgoing dependencies are more stable (have Ca>0 and higher stability): net.bytebuddy.utility (Ca=25, Ce=16, I≈0.61), net.bytebuddy.matcher (Ca=23, Ce=9, I≈0.72), net.bytebuddy.dynamic (Ca=22, Ce=24, I≈0.48), net.bytebuddy.dynamic.loading (Ca=19, Ce=15, I≈0.56), net.bytebuddy (Ca=26, Ce=25, I≈0.51), net.bytebuddy.description.type (Ca=32, Ce=16, I≈0.67), net.bytebuddy.implementation (Ca=25, Ce=23, I≈0.52). The package is unstable (Ce=8, Ca=3 -> instability I=8/(8+3)=0.727). Most other outgoing dependencies are more stable (examples: net.bytebuddy.build I≈0.345, net.bytebuddy.description.type I≈0.333, net.bytebuddy.implementation I≈0.479), but the presence of the dependency on net.bytebuddy.implementation.bind.annotation constitutes an unstable-dependency smell for this package.

org.gradle.work has Ce=1 and Ca=1 => instability I=1/(1+1)=0.5. net.bytebuddy.asm has Ce=23 and Ca=11 (instability I = Ce/(Ca+Ce) = 23/34 = 0.6765).
